Award.AwardTitle: Indigenous Ways of Doing, Knowing, and the Underlying Mathematics: Exploratory Workshop
Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a small workshop proposal to bring together Yup'ik scientists and educators with their Saami colleagues in Norway for a 3 day workshop to explore mathematics in a cultural context. The workshop will examine Yup'ik and Saami mathematical systems through their connections to practice, epistemology, and cosmology. The PI, Dr. Jerry Lipka, has been working with Yup'ik elders and teachers for several years exploring the cognitive processes behind everyday tasks or problems such as: making a pattern for clothing, a process that not only involves geometry and mathematics but encompasses Yup'ik cosmology and cultural epistemology. The purpose of the workshop is to work together with Saami people to explore the possibility of an Arctic "indigenous" cognitive process that can be understood through mathematical principles.

The workshop will take place at the Sami University College in Kautokeino, Norway. There is an expected 10-15 participants, including scholars from Taiwan, Australia, Canada and New Zealand at their own expense. In addition to the workshop the participants will be attending the World Indigenous Nations Higher Education Consortium meetings August 24th-26th.

POR.DRECONTENT:
• A long-term collaboration between Lipka (Principal Investigator) and Dora Andrew-Ihrke and Evelyn Yanez Yup’ik colleagues and former teachers and bilingual coordinators in Alaska resulted in identifying underlying mathematical processed embedded in Yup’ik everyday activities. The identified processes are: symmetry/splitting, body proportional measuring, and geometrical verification. These mathematical processes are powerful because they appear to generate an alternative and integrated approach to the teaching and learning of rational number reasoning, measuring, geometry, and early algebraic thinking. To understand if another indigenous group used similar mathematical processes in their everyday activities we held a workshop/conference with Sami and Yup’ik elders and educators. Do Sami elders while constructing everyday items such as boots, hats, and clothing would use mathematical processes similar to those used by the Yup’ik elders?
  • The major activity of the project was a two and a half day meeting/ workshop at the Sami University College that took place August 24th through August 26th 2010 in Kautokeino, Norway. The meeting was an international collaboration and it was organized by Nils Ø. Helander from the Sami University College, Ylva Nutti, from Luleå University oc Technology, Sweden, and Jerry Lipka from the University of Alaska Fairbanks. Beyond the major activity of presenting traditional ways in which Sami and Yup’ik seamstresses made everyday artifacts like boots and clothing there was additional observation of a Sami seamstress making clothing; DVD’s of the process of constructing boots and clothing were recorded and analyzed.  The findings from this project emanate both from the workshop and the analysis of DVDs
  • Interesting and importantly, each group started their project from uneven material. In fact, a major finding from this preliminary work is that both groups used the same underlying mathematics. For example, both groups used symmetry, body proportional measuring, and geometrical verification (is this side of the material equal to the other side). Although these groups are culturally and linguistically distinct, differ in terms of herding vs. subsistence-oriented society the evidence is fairly convincing that they used very similar processes. Each group used very similar body proportional measures and applied these measures in very similar ways. Further, each group embedded a problem-solving approach, that is, “how do I turn this uneven material into useable material”?  The use of symmetry/splitting to form equal partitions to the material, using a body proportional measure applicable to the person and the material, and verifying that the two sides of the material were geometrically equal represent the core processes of this approach. This was evident from each demonstration by the Sami and Yup’ik elders.
  • This work has both intellectual and potentially broader impacts. The splitting/symmetry, body proportional measuring, and geometrical verification represent a dynamic generative approach to the teaching of mathematics for young children. This appears to be true for both indigenous and non indigenous groups.
  • Although Sami and Yup’ik groups differ in many ways, they each used spatial visual methods based on perceiving the center of the material and building their artifacts from the center out; they worked from the center out in transforming uneven material and fashioning it into a product, for example a boot.
